name: Andrew Dickson White House
notes: Begun by Miller and finished by Babcock. Built for Andrew Dickson White and his family. South wing added in 1911.

name: Anabel Taylor Hall
notes: Inside is a memorial to alumni killed in World War II

name: Bard Hall
notes: Bard is attached to the east end of Thurston Hall.

name: Barnes Hall
notes: Cornell's first student union.

name: Bartels Hall
notes: Location of Newman Arena, home of the men's and women's basketball, volleyball, and wrestling teams

name: Barton Hall
notes: Originally the New York State Armory and Drill Hall, it covers an area of over two acres

name: Big Red Barn
notes: Originally the A.D. White Carriage House. Extended in 1956.

name: Computing and Communications Center
notes: Originally known as Comstock Hall; similar in design to Caldwell and Rice Halls.

name: Cornell Health
notes: Previously known as the Gannett Health Center. Built 1955-56 and designed by Conway L Todd. 1979 addition by Robert Macon Associates. A complete renovation and new addition by Chiang O'Brien along Campus Road was added in 2017 (principal Grace Chiang '80, B.Arch'81).

name: Cornell Store
notes: Built underground. Won Progressive Architecture award in January 1969.

name: Corson-Mudd Hall
notes: Includes a four-story atrium, roof-top greenhouses, and 128 research labs.

name: Day Hall
notes: University administration

name: Dolgen Hall ("ILR Extension Building")
notes: Built in 1911-1912 as an expansion of the Vet school, along with King-Shaw Hall. Rededicated "Dolgen Hall" in 2008.

name: Fernow Hall
notes: Similar to Roberts, East Roberts, Caldwell, and old Comstock Halls.

name: Foundry, The
location: 936 University Avenue, across from Milstein and Sibley
notes: Originally housed foundry casting and sand molding equipment and served as a blacksmith shop for the engineering college; part of the Architecture school since 1960.

name: Friedman Wrestling Center
notes: Said to be the "nation's first dedicated wrestling center."

name: Goldwin Smith Hall
notes: The 1892 Dairy Building was incorporated into Goldwin Smith Hall. In 2016, Klarman Hall was built against the rear of Goldwin Smith Hall.

name: Grumman Hall
notes: Similar in style to Phillips (1955), Upson (1956), and Hollister (1957)

name: Ho Plaza
notes: Central Avenue from Campus Road to Uris Library was converted to a pedestrian mall

name: Hollister Hall
notes: DeFrees Hydraulics Laboratory was added in 1982

name: Hughes Hall
notes: Renovated in 2017

name: Ives Hall East
notes: Low, horizontal building with flat roof. Formerly the site of the James Law Hall, Veterinary School

name: Kennedy Hall
notes: The south section is Kennedy, the north section is Roberts. Stone Hall was demolished to make way for this.

name: Kimball Hall
notes: Eastern Pavilion of Thurston Hall

name: King-Shaw Hall ("ILR Conference Center")
notes: Built in 1911-1912 as an expansion of the Vet school. Rededicated "King-Shaw Hall" in 2012. Designed after an eighteenth-century colonial estate

name: Kinzelberg Hall
notes: Nutritional Sciences

name: Klarman Hall
architect: Koetter, Kim and Associates (Alfred H. Koetter Jr., M.Arch. ‚Äô66 and Susie Sung-Hea Kim ‚Äô71, B.Arch. ‚Äô72)
notes: The exterior rear of Goldwin Smith forms the west side wall of Klarman.

name: Kroch Library
notes: A three-story underground library, accessible through Olin Library.

name: Lincoln Hall
notes: Originally home of civil engineering and architecture; later shared by Theatre Arts and Music; now Music. Major expansion of Lincoln Hall along East Avenue for the Music Department.

name: Livestock Pavilion
notes: Similar in style to Wing Hall

name: Malott Hall
location: 212 Garden Ave., across from Bailey Hall

name: McGraw Hall
notes: Originally housed the library and a Museum of Zoology

name: McGraw Tower (University Chimes)
notes: McGraw Tower stands 173 feet tall and contains 131 steps to the clock mechanism, and 30 more steps to the bell loft. The chimes were donated to Cornell by Jennie McGraw in 1868 and installed in McGraw Tower in 1891.

name: Milstein Hall
notes: Connects to Rand and Sibley halls, and cantilevers over University Avenue.

name: Morrill Hall
notes: The first academic building built for Cornell; when the university opened in 1868, Morrill and Cascadilla Hall were the only buildings on campus.

name: Morrison Hall
notes: Designed to match Riley-Robb Hall

name: Myron Taylor Hall
notes: Addition built in 1987-89 to match Myron Taylor's College Gothic style.  The addition includes a second tower, an atrium, library and office space.

name: Newman (Floyd R.) Laboratory
notes: Opened as "Laboratory of Nuclear Studies."

name: Olin Hall
notes: The first Engineering building outside Sibley Hall

name: Olin Library
notes: Boardman Hall was demolished to create space for Olin Library.

name: Phillips Hall
location: East end of the Engineering Quad; 116 Hoy Rd

name: Physical Sciences Building
architect: Koetter, Kim and Associates (Alfred H. Koetter Jr., M.Arch. ‚Äô66 and Susie Sung-Hea Kim ‚Äô71, B.Arch. ‚Äô72)
notes: Connects Baker Lab and Clark Hall

name: Plant Science Building and Greenhouses
location: East side of Ag Quad, 236 Tower Road

name: Post (Kenneth) Laboratory
notes: Floriculture and ornamental horticulture

name: Rand Hall
notes: Originally contained the machine shop, pattern shop, and electrical laboratory; renovated 2018‚Äì2019.

name: Rice Hall
notes: One of the original Ag Quad buildings, in a similar style. Originally named Poultry Building.

name: Roberts Hall
notes: The south section of this structure is known as Kennedy Hall, while the northern end is called Roberts Hall.

name: Rockefeller Hall
notes: 1980 renovation by Levatich & Hoffman

name: Sage Chapel
notes: The Sage Memorial Apse was added in 1898. The north transept was added in 1904.

name: Sage Hall
notes: Renovated for SC Johnson School of Management

name: Savage Hall
notes: 1988 addition by King & King Architects

name: Schoellkopf Crescent
notes: Crescent design with arches was added in 1923.

name: Schoellkopf House
notes: One-story square building on the east side of Schoellkopf Hall

name: Schurman Hall
notes: Three-story structure with flat roof

name: Sibley Dome
architect: Archimedes Russell, Charles Osborne, Gibb and Waltz (Arthur N. Gibb '91)
notes: Sibley Hall was built in three distinct stages as the Sibley College of Mechanical Engineering and the Mechanic Arts. The West building was built first, in three stories; expanded to five in 1884. East Sibley and West Sibley were connected in 1902 by the middle building, which contained a dome, large auditorium, and museum.

name: Snee Hall
notes: Contains the department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, as well as a geology museum.

name: Space Sciences Building
notes: In 1987 the Ithaca firm Holt Architects added two floors to the top of the building.

name: Statler Hotel
notes: The earlier Statler Inn stood on this site; it was demolished and a larger hotel built on the same site in 1989 and rechristened the Statler Hotel.

name: Stimson Hall
notes: Originally built for the Ithaca Division of the Cornell University Medical College, whose main building was located in New York City.

name: Stocking  Hall West
notes: Beaux-Arts style with mansard roofs; extended 1964; interior renovation by Ulrich Franzen in 1968.

name: Teagle Hall
architect: Francis Day Rogers and Jonathan Fairchild Butler

name: Olive Tjaden Hall
notes: Originally Franklin Hall, was home to chemistry and physics; later it became the electrical engineering building; renamed for donor and architect Olive Tjaden in 1981. The steeple was damaged by a storm in the 1950s, and restored in September 1997; the building's interior was gutted and renovated at that time.

name: Upson Hall
location: SE corner of Engineering Quad (124 Hoy Road)

name: Veterinary Research Tower
notes: Reclad and redesigned in 2019 by Weiss/Manfredi

name: Warren Hall
notes: 1958 addition connected Warren with Mann Library

name: Weill Hall
notes: 263,000-square-foot building for the life sciences

name: White Hall
architect: Harlow M Wilcox & Cyrus K Porter

name: Willard Straight Hall
notes: Originally the large north entrance was for men, the smaller south entrance for women. Extension added 1954.

name: Becker (Carl) House
notes: Built as part of the "West Campus Initiative."

name: Bethe (Hans) House
notes: Built as part of the "West Campus Initiative."

name: Boldt Hall
notes: Day & Klauder designed all the West Campus buildings between 1913 and 1931. The firm was just Klauder after Day died in 1918.

name: Collyer Boathouse
notes: Expansion and renovation 2010-2011 by HGA Architects

name: Deke House
notes: Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity house.

name: Eddy Gate
location: End of Eddy Street behind Cascadilla Hall

name: Founders Hall
architect: Frank Miles Day & Charles Zeller Klauder
notes: Founders Hall was the second of the West Campus men's dormitories (women lived on North Campus). Day & Klauder designed all the West Campus Gothic buildings between 1913 and 1931.

name: Hartung-Boothroyd Observatory
notes: Used mainly as a teaching facility for upper-level undergraduate astronomy classes

name: Keeton (William T.) House
notes: Built as part of the "West Campus Initiative."

name: Llenroc
notes: Built as Ezra Cornell's mansion. Sold to Delta Phi fraternity in 1911.

name: Lyon/McFaddin/War Memorial
notes: Lyon and McFaddin towers originally represented the Army and Navy, respectively.

name: Mennen Hall
notes: Mennen Hall was the final West Campus residence hall constructed in College Gothic style.

name: Noyes Community and Recreation Center
notes: Fitness center, climbing wall, air hockey tables, basketball court, game center, and convenience store.

name: Rose (Flora) House
notes: Built as part of the "West Campus Initiative."

name: Schuyler House
notes: Originally served as the campus infirmary, later used for student housing. A large addition was added in 1911.

name: Schwartz Performing Arts Center
notes: Performing arts education, professional training and public performance

name: Sheldon Court
notes: Originally a private dormitory for men with shops on the first floor, it was willed to Cornell by Charles Sheldon in 1914. Renovated 1982.

name: Telluride House
notes: A residential intellectual society

name: Von Cramm Cooperative Hall
notes: A student operated house.

name: Anna Comstock House
notes: Home to the Latino Living Center.

name: Balch Hall
notes: Balch is a collection of four 80-student residence halls around a central courtyard.

name: Fuertes Observatory
architect: L.P. Burnham, Cornell Professor of Architecture
notes: The current building is "the fourth or fifth" astronomical observatory on the Cornell campus

name: Mary Donlon Hall
notes: Renovated by Holt Architects in 2003

name: Noyes Lodge
notes: Built in 1958 as a dining hall, known for many years as "The Pancake House." 2018 renovation by JMZ Architects redesigned Noyes as the Martin Y. Tang Welcome Center.

name: Risley Hall
notes: Originally opened to accommodate the growing enrollment of women,

name: Ujamaa (Low Rise 10)
notes: A long rectangular building with projecting wings

name: Appel Commons
notes: Dining, fitness center

name: Mews Hall
notes: 87,129 sq ft; 260+ beds

name: Barbara McClintock Hall
notes: 103,835 sq ft; 311 beds

name: Hu Shih Hall
notes: 138,773 sq ft; 429 beds

name: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Hall
notes: 162,849 sq ft; 504 beds
